text: <@U015HDJKZM2> You might also be interested in _Pricing Design_ by Dan Brown. He wrote it for UX designers, but the theory and language is helpful for content folks, too.

text: Super short book you can read in an hour.

text:
Hi, everyone. I'm genuinely curious about why potential clients/employers ghost people. Recently, I've had two businesses ask for content help. (Well, I have had more than two ask, but two that ended with ghosting.) I replied to both and received fast responses. Despite rapid-fire friendly and encouraging back-and-forth messages, a meeting in one case, and fulfilling a couple of info/idea requests, both have gone silent.

So here's my question: do these people not respond because they've decided against you and don't want to hurt your feelings? Are they so busy that they no longer have time to send you an email? Is the norm now not to respond if the answer is "no?" Have they stolen my ideas (despite me reminding them of my ownership) so know they don't need me? Seriously, I'd love to understand the thinking.

Seriously, I'd love to understand the thinking.

text:
it's super frustrating when prospects ghost you, especially when you've invested a bunch of time and energy into it.

i think typically it's just a form of conflict avoidance and taking the easy way out.

from a process perspective, i think it's useful to write out what level of reciprocal commitment you need from them to do x. e.g., i won't do x unless they've paid/signed a contract/whatever.

text:
I'm so sorry about your experience <@U0162CX5SH1>. Just last month, I was ghosted by two potential clients too.

Like <@U011UJX75PE> said, ghosting is a form of conflict avoidance and most people will prefer that to sending a rejection email.

While there is no way to 100% prevent prospects from ghosting you, I believe you can pre-qualify them and see if they're a right fit "budget-wise" before scheduling a meeting. Here is a blog post that I believe you mind find helpful: <https://www.jennifergregorywriter.com/2020/08/17/the-one-thing-you-must-do-before-getting-on-the-phone-with-a-client/>

attachments.text: A potential client contacted me with a seemingly great project and asked for a call to talk more. We set up a time and had a great call – nice people, regular work and great clips. At the end of the call, they ask me to send over my rates and then we could start…

text: One piece of nuance to consider is to ask whether you're presenting yourself to clients as a staff augmentation/contractor/individual or whether you're presenting yourself as a vendor.  If it's the former, then it's probably some combination of rudeness/forgetfulness/inconsideration.  If it's the latter, it's because ghosting vendors after tire-kicking calls is the way of the world, so to speak.

elements.text: One piece of nuance to consider is to ask whether you're presenting yourself to clients as a staff augmentation/contractor/individual or whether you're presenting yourself as a vendor.  If it's the former, then it's probably some combination of rudeness/forgetfulness/inconsideration.  If it's the latter, it's because ghosting vendors after tire-kicking calls is the way of the world, so to speak.

text: When I look at my business's CRM, we have an entire column for "gone dark post sales call" and that's what happens with maybe 25% of all sales calls.

elements.text: When I look at my business's CRM, we have an entire column for "gone dark post sales call" and that's what happens with maybe 25% of all sales calls.

text: I don't really think anything about those prospects one way or the other -- I just assume they're shopping around and they either found what they needed elsewhere or put their project on hold

elements.text: I don't really think anything about those prospects one way or the other -- I just assume they're shopping around and they either found what they needed elsewhere or put their project on hold

text: I guess I'd put it this way.  Imagine if you were calling 3-4 plumbers to get a price/estimate on fixing a leak.  You probably wouldn't call each one back to say, "I'm sorry, but I went in a different direction."  And, if you did, they'd probably respond with, "huh, who are you?"

elements.text: I guess I'd put it this way.  Imagine if you were calling 3-4 plumbers to get a price/estimate on fixing a leak.  You probably wouldn't call each one back to say, "I'm sorry, but I went in a different direction."  And, if you did, they'd probably respond with, "huh, who are you?"

text: Interesting perspective. If someone gave me the trouble of providing a quote via email, I actually would respond (and have).

elements.text: Interesting perspective. If someone gave me the trouble of providing a quote via email, I actually would respond (and have).

text: Oh, don't get me wrong.  I'd respond too, if I got the feeling that effort had gone into a quote and, especially if it were an independent contractor, rather than an agency that cranks out quotes/bids.  But that kind of feeds into the same theme of "the more you look like an (established) vendor, the less people think of ghosting you."

elements.text: Oh, don't get me wrong.  I'd respond too, if I got the feeling that effort had gone into a quote and, especially if it were an independent contractor, rather than an agency that cranks out quotes/bids.  But that kind of feeds into the same theme of "the more you look like an (established) vendor, the less people think of ghosting you."

text: I'm guessing the biggest inflection point happens when people perceive the business/vendor has a dedicated salesperson.  That means their job is to create proposals and do sales calls, so ghosters probably just subconsciously shrug and figure "they get paid either way"

elements.text: I'm guessing the biggest inflection point happens when people perceive the business/vendor has a dedicated salesperson.  That means their job is to create proposals and do sales calls, so ghosters probably just subconsciously shrug and figure "they get paid either way"

text:
Little late to the party here, but something I’ve done is use the resource library on the website, but have a special address or cookie that lets sales and other visitors skip all the forms, etc. Seemed to work pretty well.

I also have found, like <@URAV154AV>, that yeah, you gotta market all of it internally :slightly_smiling_face: So building that into your workflow is helpful.

text:
Hi Trevor, a bit late to the thread, but our content team uses a VA, and I completely agree with <@URA4VBQ2X> – they’re a valued part of making sure things run smoothly. 

We generally assign VAs with routine tasks we feel they can handle fairly independently (i.e., outreach, responding to queries). This frees us up to do things only our in-house team would be familiar with. As long as there’s clear communication and process, it ends up being a great working relationship.
